The National Consortium For Data Science (NCDS) is a collaboration of leaders in academia, industry and government formed to address the data challenges of the 21st century.  The NCDS was founded as a mechanism to help the U.S. take advantage of the ever increasing flow of digital data in ways that result in new jobs and industries, new advances in healthcare, transformative discoveries in science, and competitive advantages for U.S. industry.

To fully unleash the power of big data, the U.S. must develop and master data science—the systematic study of digital data. The National Consortium for Data Science provides the structure and leadership to cultivate a focused data science community and break through the challenges of big data to drive the field forward.

With 30+ years of experience as a writer, editor and public relations director, Jennifer retired from NC State University in January 2019 and now provides freelance services as a science writer and editor. Jennifer is a member of the National Association of Science Writers (NASW) and serves on the board of directors and on the program committee for the annual Science Writers conference. She has also served as judge for the Excellence in Institutional Writing Award-Long Form, and on the communications working committee. She served as chair of the communications committee for the 10th World Conference of Science Journalists from 2016-2017 and serves in other volunteer capacities for NASW. She is also a member of the board of directors for the Science Communicators of North Carolina (SCONC). She currently serves as treasurer for SCONC and as SCONC's SciWri Congress representative. Jennifer's interests span a variety of science and engineering fields from anthropology and geography to paleontology and zoology and most everything in-between.

As a teaching assistant professor at UNC Chapel Hill, my goal is to demystify computer programming.   For example, while teaching Comp 116, Introduction to Scientific Programming, to non-computer science majors the goal is not only teach Python, NumPy, and SciPy but to make collecting data, analyzing data, and visualizing data a normal part of the scientific discovery process.  Computers are part of our everyday lives.  They should not be mystical black boxes.  They are tools we all use and need to understand.
